snippet.textDisplay: I would like to know if this mask is a one time use? If not, what are your laundering instructions to keep it as sanitary and as reliable as it was before use or after being in any type of virus exposure?

snippet.textDisplay:
Recommendation: before top stitching, put a small wire (bread tie, unbent paper clip, pipe cleaner, floral wire 3-4"long ) down close to the original seam (the 1/4" seam allowance without pressing it open leaves a channel) then "stitch in the ditch" close to the wire so that it is sealed between the original seam and the top stitch around it. Existing masks can be "retrofitted" with this method.
The wire improves the mask to make it easier to breath through, fit more comfortably, and seal out more germs.
snippet.textOriginal:
Recommendation:  before top stitching, put a small wire (bread tie, unbent paper clip, pipe cleaner, floral  wire 3-4"long ) down close to the original seam (the 1/4" seam  allowance without pressing it open leaves a channel) then "stitch in the ditch" close to the wire so that it is sealed between the original seam and the top stitch around it.  Existing masks can be "retrofitted" with this method.
The wire improves the mask to make it easier to breath through, fit more comfortably, and seal out more germs.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi!  I’ve watched several of these tutorials now in preparation for making masks for my family.  I was going to make some for our healthcare project, but my husband already asked a local tailor to make about 200 of them!  So I’m off the hook there.  Your instructions were so clear and easy to follow that your tutorial is the one I’m following after all the others I watched.  I don’t have flannel and I don’t think the interfacing I have would work very well for this, and the local fabric shops don’t carry any flannels, so I’m just going with the two layers of very tightly woven fabric.  Your tutorial is so easy to follow that I’m going to have my kids help me make their masks (ages 5 and 4).  They are super excited.  The one thing I did differently was to make three pleats, instead of two, as that’s what was shown on a different tutorial.  My husband could have used a little bit longer bands, I could have used a bit smaller, and I’ll probably measure the kids to get their fit, but it’s easily adjustable for mine.  My husband just chose one that had turned out a bit bigger.
snippet.textOriginal: Hi!  I’ve watched several of these tutorials now in preparation for making masks for my family.  I was going to make some for our healthcare project, but my husband already asked a local tailor to make about 200 of them!  So I’m off the hook there.  Your instructions were so clear and easy to follow that your tutorial is the one I’m following after all the others I watched.  I don’t have flannel and I don’t think the interfacing I have would work very well for this, and the local fabric shops don’t carry any flannels, so I’m just going with the two layers of very tightly woven fabric.  Your tutorial is so easy to follow that I’m going to have my kids help me make their masks (ages 5 and 4).  They are super excited.  The one thing I did differently was to make three pleats, instead of two, as that’s what was shown on a different tutorial.  My husband could have used a little bit longer bands, I could have used a bit smaller, and I’ll probably measure the kids to get their fit, but it’s easily adjustable for mine.  My husband just chose one that had turned out a bit bigger.

snippet.textDisplay:
I really wish I was remotely good at sewing; my silly un-nimble fingers from being disabled just can’t get the knack ! These would be so tremendously helpful to my family, myself & my elderly neighbours right now, who, despite the majority needing to self isolate, some are still able to go out & get basic necessities (our shelves still haven’t been restocked through no fault of the workers, they’re trying so hard & people are still stockpiling leaving nothing for the vulnerable or the medical workers on the frontline!)
Wonderful idea though, I hope this helps so many at a time like this! Thank you for sharing 💕 xx
snippet.textOriginal:
I *really* wish I was remotely good at sewing; my silly un-nimble fingers from being disabled just can’t get the knack ! These would be so tremendously helpful to my family, myself & my elderly neighbours right now, who, despite the majority needing to self isolate, some are still able to go out & get basic necessities (our shelves still haven’t been restocked through no fault of the workers, they’re trying so hard & people are still stockpiling leaving nothing for the vulnerable or the medical workers on the frontline!)
Wonderful idea though, I hope this helps so many at a time like this! Thank you for sharing 💕 xx

snippet.textDisplay: You mentioned giving back to your community? Corporations received tax breaks to bring their manufacturing back to the states and create living wage jobs. The shortage of medical face masks is the result of the corporations never bringing factories back and relying on China to make their products. People's lives are in jeopardy now. Look how many people are making these with their own money. Home sewers have not received any tax breaks nor are we getting paid to make these masks. When this pandemic is over our communities need to confront these corporations and our government for giving tax breaks to those corporations that did nothing for the people.

snippet.textDisplay: Please remember that these fabric  masks will be sterilized or washed in very hot water. Synthetic materials will melt/shrink. If you use cotton interfacing (which has a polyester scrim) prewash it so that it doesn't shrink up your mask in the hot wash. Fabric stores do sell 100% cotton batting with no poly scrim for use in microwave projects; but, those stores may be closed right now. By the way, with this coronavirus, health care providers are wearing surgical goggles to cover their eyes, and these will hold down the top edge of the mask over the nose.
snippet.textOriginal: Please remember that these fabric  masks will be sterilized or washed in very hot water. Synthetic materials will melt/shrink. If you use cotton interfacing (which has a polyester scrim) prewash it so that it doesn't shrink up your mask in the hot wash. Fabric stores do sell 100% cotton batting with no poly scrim for use in microwave projects; but, those stores may be closed right now. By the way, with this coronavirus, health care providers are wearing surgical goggles to cover their eyes, and these will hold down the top edge of the mask over the nose.

snippet.textDisplay: These don’t work!! Drs & nurses on the front lines will tell you this. Only N95 masks work & those have to be worn correctly to seal properly. It’s misleading to tell people that these can protect us. The N95 ones should only be used by the healthcare people so they don’t run out of PPE. Staying home. Social distancing. Help stop the spread. Wear gloves to handle everything if you have to go out. Gas pumps , your mail, etc. Wash hands. Use sanitizers that are at least 60% alcohol. All this advice is from nurses I know personally. May God bless you all thru this crazy tough time. Be kind to others
snippet.textOriginal: These don’t work!! Drs & nurses on the front lines will tell you this. Only N95 masks work & those have to be worn correctly to seal properly.
